# Your Job

Research and analyze today's stock market performance (February 6, 2025) and the factors behind any market rebound. Create a comprehensive research document that covers:

1. Today's market performance - major indices (S&P 500, Dow, Nasdaq) and their movements
2. Key factors driving any market rebound or recovery
3. Sector analysis - which sectors led gains/losses
4. Notable individual stock performances
5. Economic news, earnings reports, or policy announcements that influenced trading
6. Market sentiment and investor reactions
7. Analyst commentary and expert opinions on the rebound

Create a new directory called "stocks" in the repository root and save all findings in a well-structured markdown file at "stocks/RESEARCH.md". The research should be thorough, citing sources where possible, and provide clear insights into what drove today's market movements.

Use web search capabilities to gather current market data, news articles, and expert analysis from reputable financial sources like Bloomberg, Reuters, CNBC, MarketWatch, and WSJ.

content.text:
---
name: brave-search
description: Web search and content extraction via Brave Search API. Use for searching documentation, facts, or any web content. Lightweight, no browser required.
---

# Brave Search

Web search and content extraction using the official Brave Search API. No browser required.

## Setup

Requires a Brave Search API account with a free subscription. A credit card is required to create the free subscription (you won't be charged).

1. Create an account at https://api-dashboard.search.brave.com/register
2. Create a "Free AI" subscription
3. Create an API key for the subscription
4. Add to your shell profile (`~/.profile` or `~/.zprofile` for zsh):
   ```bash
   export BRAVE_API_KEY="your-api-key-here"
   ```
5. Install dependencies (run once):
   ```bash
   cd {baseDir}
   npm install
   ```

## Search

```bash
{baseDir}/search.js "query"                         # Basic search (5 results)
{baseDir}/search.js "query" -n 10                   # More results (max 20)
{baseDir}/search.js "query" --content               # Include page content as markdown
{baseDir}/search.js "query" --freshness pw          # Results from last week
{baseDir}/search.js "query" --freshness 2024-01-01to2024-06-30  # Date range
{baseDir}/search.js "query" --country DE            # Results from Germany
{baseDir}/search.js "query" -n 3 --content          # Combined options
```

### Options

- `-n <num>` - Number of results (default: 5, max: 20)
- `--content` - Fetch and include page content as markdown
- `--country <code>` - Two-letter country code (default: US)
- `--freshness <period>` - Filter by time:
  - `pd` - Past day (24 hours)
  - `pw` - Past week
  - `pm` - Past month
  - `py` - Past year
  - `YYYY-MM-DDtoYYYY-MM-DD` - Custom date range

## Extract Page Content

```bash
{baseDir}/content.js https://example.com/article
```

Fetches a URL and extracts readable content as markdown.

## Output Format

```
--- Result 1 ---
Title: Page Title
Link: https://example.com/page
Age: 2 days ago
Snippet: Description from search results
Content: (if --content flag used)
  Markdown content extracted from the page...

--- Result 2 ---
...
```

## When to Use

- Searching for documentation or API references
- Looking up facts or current information
- Fetching content from specific URLs
- Any task requiring web search without interactive browsing

# Markets News, Feb. 6, 2026: Dow Ends Above 50K for First Time as Indexes Soar After 3-Day Sell-Off; Bitcoin Bounces Back Above $70K

Major stock indexes bounced back sharply Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing above the 50,000 threshold for the first time, a day after equities sank amid risk-off sentiment. 

The blue-chip [Dow Jones Industrial Average](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/d/djia.asp), benchmark [S&P 500](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/s/sp500.asp), and tech-heavy [Nasdaq](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/n/nasdaq.asp) soared 2.5%, 2%, and 2.2%, respectively, with the Dow soaring more than 1,200 points to 50,137, topping its all-time high set Tuesday.

Although the Dow snapped a three-week losing streak, the Nasdaq extended its skid to four weeks and the S&P 500 fell for the third time in four weeks.

The Dow was paced Friday by shares of AI darling Nvidia ([NVDA](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=nvda)), which soared nearly 8%, and construction-equipment maker Caterpillar ([CAT](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=cat)), which surged 7%.

Amazon ([AMZN](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=amzn)) stock [sank](https://www.investopedia.com/amazon-is-the-dow-weakest-performer-friday-here-is-why-11901053) more than 5.5% to lead Dow decliners following a [disappointing earnings report](https://www.investopedia.com/amazon-follows-google-microsoft-with-a-big-boost-in-ai-spending-the-stock-is-tumbling-amzn-11900825) after the bell yesterday. Another notable tech company, Qualcomm ([QCOM](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=qcom)), rebounded nearly 1% after its [stock sank 8.5% yesterday](https://www.investopedia.com/qualcomm-disappointing-outlook-stokes-worries-about-a-global-memory-shortage-the-stock-is-tumbling-qcom-11900057) after executives attributed the firm's soft current-quarter forecasts to the global memory shortage.

Shares of ["Big Three" automaker](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/bigthree.asp) Stellantis ([STLA](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=stla)) plummeted 25% after it announced [a business "reset"](https://www.investopedia.com/stellantis-shares-are-tumbling-to-their-lowest-point-in-over-5-years-here-is-why-11901026) that includes a roughly $26 billion charge.

In post-earnings moves, shares of Roblox ([RBLX](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=rblx)) surged almost 10%, Doximity ([DOCS](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=docs)) dropped 17%, Molina Healthcare ([MOH](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=moh)) plunged 26% to lead Nasdaq decliners, and Coty ([COTY](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=coty)) stock retreated 16%.

Bitcoin tumbled yesterday and sank to just above $60,000 overnight—its lowest level since October 2024—before rebounding above $70,700 at 4 p.m. ET. Shares of bitcoin treasury firm Strategy ([MSTR](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=mstr)) jumped 25% to lead the Nasdaq after diving 17% to pace index decliners yesterday, and crypto-tied firms MARA Holdings ([MARA](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=mara)), Robinhood Markets ([HOOD](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=hood)), and Coinbase Global ([COIN](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=coin)) rebounded a respective 22%, 14%, and 13%.

Silver futures edged higher to about $77 an ounce, well off their high of about $121.75 on Jan. 29. Gold futures, which had surged to roughly $5,625 an ounce the same day last week, were up nearly 2% to $4,975.

The yield on the [10-year Treasury](https://www.investopedia.com/articles/investing/100814/why-10-year-us-treasury-rates-matter.asp)—which impacts interest rates on a variety of consumer loans including mortgages—rose to about 4.21% from Thursday's close of 4.18%. 

[West Texas Intermediate](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/w/wti.asp) crude futures, the U.S. benchmark, ticked higher to $63.40 a barrel. The U.S. dollar index, which tracks the value of the greenback against a basket of global currencies, was down slightly at 97.63. 

February 06, 2026 04:21 PM EST

## 

**The Once-Hot AI Trade Hit a Snag. Some Experts Call That a 'Fantastic' Sign** 

FROM 3 hr 5 min ago

AI was the rising tide lifting all boats. These days, it’s sinking as many as it’s lifting. 

Investor anxiety is building in tandem with Big Tech’s AI spending, creating an environment in which the slightest whiff of uncertainty can wreak havoc on stocks. The four hyperscalers that reported earnings in the past two weeks—Meta ([META](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=META)), Microsoft ([MSFT](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=MSFT)), Alphabet ([GOOG](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=GOOG), [GOOGL](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=GOOGL)), and Amazon ([AMZN](https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=AMZN))—all laid out plans to continue aggressively investing in AI infrastructure.

Tech stocks sold off this week amid worries about excess AI spending and disruption of the software industry.

Michael Nagle / Bloomberg via Getty Images

Alphabet and Meta say this year’s infrastructure spending will be about double last year’s. Amazon on Thursday forecast 2026 [capital expenditures](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/capitalexpenditure.asp) of $200 billion, a 50% year-over-year increase and about $50 billion more than Wall Street expected. Microsoft didn’t provide a dollar estimate, but its capital spending the rest of the year is expected to be consistent with last quarter, when it rose by more than 60%.

Read the full story [here](https://www.investopedia.com/the-once-hot-ai-trade-hit-a-snag-some-experts-call-that-a-fantastic-sign-nvda-stock-11901491).

\-[_Colin Laidley_](https://www.investopedia.com/colin-laidley-5218536)

February 06, 2026 04:18 PM EST

## 

**Is The Economy's Balance 'Precarious' or 'Stabilizing?' Fed Officials Differ** 

FROM 3 hr 8 min ago

Federal Reserve officials gave contrasting assessments of the economic outlook Friday, with one having "cautious optimism" and the other noting that to workers, the situation seems "precarious."

In separate statements, Fed Governor Philip Jefferson and Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly discussed how the job market has been slower than usual in recent months, although employers have avoided mass layoffs so far. Jefferson, speaking at the Brookings Institution think tank in Washington, noted the [unemployment rate, at 4.4% in December](https://www.investopedia.com/the-job-market-stayed-cool-in-december-11882200), has "changed little" in recent months, suggesting that the job market is stabilizing after a slowdown.

Job seekers may be feeling a bit skeptical about the future of the economy.

Spencer Platt / Getty Images

Daly, in a blog post, highlighted that working households [don't feel optimistic these days](https://www.investopedia.com/consumer-confidence-hits-new-low-yet-spending-remains-strong-whats-driving-this-paradox-11893491), cautiously or otherwise. Recent surveys of consumer sentiment show that people expect unemployment to rise and jobs to become more scarce over the next six months. And open positions are already pretty hard to come by, having [fallen to their lowest since the pandemic in December](https://www.investopedia.com/the-job-market-froze-over-this-winter-11900274).

Read the full story [here](https://www.investopedia.com/is-the-economy-s-balance-precarious-or-stabilizing-fed-officials-differ-11901669).

## 

**Almost Entire Dow Jones Industrial Average Higher Friday**

# Dow soars by 1,200 points as Wall Street rebounds from tech meltdown

New York  — 

The sell-off in tech stocks screeched to a halt Friday as investors stepped in to buy the dip: The Dow soared 1,207 points, or 2.47%, and hit [50,000 points](https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/06/investing/dow-index-us-stocks-50k) for the first time ever. The tech-heavy Nasdaq rose 2.18% and the S&P 500 rose 1.97%.

The Dow and S&P each posted their best day since May. The Nasdaq had its best day since November.

Tech stocks had dragged down Wall Street earlier this week as investors fled once-hot shares, and Friday’s fierce rally comes after the Nasdaq’s [worst three-day slide](https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/05/investing/us-stock-market) since April. The index had shed more than $1.5 trillion in market value this week before rebounding Friday.

It’s been a turbulent few days for Wall Street, Big Tech and the entire software industry. Here’s why:

* Nerves about AI tools disrupting business models are hurting software stocks.
* Investors are becoming skeptical about Big Tech’s massive spending spree on building data centers to power the AI boom.
* Tech stocks were already expensive from big gains in recent years, making them susceptible to a “shoot first and ask questions later” sell-off.
* The AI tide lifted all boats for a while; now, Wall Street has to get picky about winners and losers.

“Recent months have seen a shift from the ‘every tech stock is a winner’ mindset to a more brutal landscape of winners and losers,” Jim Reid, head of global macro research at Deutsche Bank, said in a Thursday note.

A sell-off in risky assets like bitcoin — which just hit its [lowest level since October 2024](https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/05/investing/bitcoin-price) — also probably fueled investors’ desire for safer assets earlier this week. Bitcoin rebounded Friday, soaring 10% to roughly $70,000.

“Stocks are off to a volatile start in February,” Clark Bellin, president and chief investment officer at Bellwether Wealth, said in a note.

“The bull market is not dead, but it is aging, and we are not surprised to see investors paying more attention to corporate earnings and profitability,” Bellin said.

AI startup Anthropic on Friday released new tools that the company says can do more tasks for the legal industry. That [made Wall Street nervous](https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/04/investing/us-stocks-anthropic-software) that companies will soon be able to dump their existing, specialized subscriptions to data analytics and research software, directly hurting software companies’ bottom lines.

The jury is still out on whether that will actually happen. But investors were spooked and dumped shares in legal and financial software and services companies.

There have been nerves about AI eating into software’s market share for a while: Salesforce ([CRM](https://www.cnn.com/markets/stocks/CRM)), a software company in the blue-chip Dow index, slumped 20% in 2025 and is down 28% so far this year.

Meanwhile, Wall Street is in the midst of corporate earnings season. There are lingering concerns (remember [nerves about an AI bubble?](https://www.cnn.com/2025/12/19/tech/ai-chips-lifecycle-questions)) about Big Tech’s aspirations to build out massive data centers and infrastructure to power the AI boom and uncertainty about just how profitable that building rush will prove.

Microsoft ([MSFT](https://www.cnn.com/markets/stocks/MSFT)), Alphabet ([GOOG](https://www.cnn.com/markets/stocks/GOOG)) and Amazon ([AMZN](https://www.cnn.com/markets/stocks/AMZN)) all outlined plans across the past week to increase their spending on building data centers and infrastructure.

Wall Street wants to see evidence that these enormous expenditures will result in actual profits. Microsoft shares dropped 10% on January 29 after the company reported earnings. Amazon shares fell roughly 5.6% Friday after the company’s reported earnings Thursday afternoon.

“The bar for Big Tech remains extremely high,” Seana Smith, senior investment strategist at Global X ETFs, told CNN.

“Markets are only rewarding AI investment when it is paired with clear, durable revenue growth,” Smith said.

The AI theme has driven the stock market higher across the past three years. Some investors are balking at paying those high prices and are instead looking for off-ramps.

Shares of chipmaker Advanced Micro Devices ([AMD](https://www.cnn.com/markets/stocks/AMD)) on Wednesday sank 17% and had their worst day since 2017 after the company forecast slightly less revenue in the first quarter than analysts had expected. AMD shares rebounded 8% on Friday.

Valuations, a measure of how pricey stocks are, have been elevated for some tech companies. Palantir ([PLTR](https://www.cnn.com/markets/stocks/PLTR)), a star of the AI trade, surged 340% in 2024 and 135% in 2025. Palantir is now down 35% from its record high in early November.

Oracle shares ([ORCL](https://www.cnn.com/markets/stocks/ORCL)) [hit a record high](https://www.cnn.com/2025/09/16/tech/oracle-larry-ellison-ai-computing) on September 10 after the company announced a $300 billion deal with OpenAI. Oracle shares have tanked 59% since then.

“Crowded trades are difficult to exit,” Steve Sosnick, chief strategist at Interactive Brokers, said in a note. “Assets that have been granted premium valuations, whether through rational expectations or speculative fervor, are more prone to messy selloffs if perceptions and/or momentum change.”

## Winners and losers

In recent years, anything related to AI has been a hot trade on Wall Street. But now investors need to get picky about specific companies they think will benefit.

“Consensus about software companies has flipped to them being AI victims, not beneficiaries,” Sosnick at Interactive Brokers told CNN.

“The rising tide surrounding AI was lifting a lot of boats,” Sosnick said. “Now it’s forcing Wall Street to be much more selective and really decide who are the winners and losers. And that’s going to require a lot more detailed analysis, rather than just sort of riding the momentum train.”

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang said this week the idea that software will be replaced by AI was “illogical,” according to [Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/business/nvidias-huang-dismisses-fears-ai-will-replace-software-tools-stock-selloff-2026-02-04/).

Barclays backs up that sentiment. “It just does not seem realistic” that AI companies can supplant those industry-specific software tools, wrote Nick Dempsey, direct of media equity research at Barclays, in a note. But with markets this touchy, headlines about the possibility are “clearly not helpful,” he added.

An exchange-traded fund tracking the software industry rose roughly 3% on Friday, pausing an eight-day slide.

“At this point, the negativity surrounding AI-related tech is getting pretty intense,” Tom Essaye, president of Sevens Report Research, said in a note.

“Granted, there are reasons for the skepticism, but the declines in some of these stocks are substantial, and if AI is more resilient than expected (which has been the case in each test so far over the past three years), then there are opportunities \[for buying\] developing,” Essaye said.

Separately, chipmakers also gained Friday as Big Tech’s plans for data centers will likely boost demand for semiconductor chips. Nvidia shares ([NVDA](https://www.cnn.com/markets/stocks/NVDA)) soared 7.78% and had their best day since April.

“When you pull the beach ball underwater that quickly in places like Big Tech, certainly software and semis, the bounce back can be breathtaking,” Chris Galipeau, senior market strategist at Franklin Templeton, told CNN.

CNN’s Matt Egan contributed reporting

# Dow surges 1,200 points for first close above 50,000 in sharp rebound from tech rout: Live updates

3 Hours Ago

## Stocks close higher

The three leading U.S. indexes finished solidly higher on Friday.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 1,206.95 points, or 2.47%, to close at 50,115.67 — its first close above 50,000. The S&P 500 gained 1.97% to end at 6,932.30, while the Nasdaq Composite advanced 2.18% to 23,031.21.

_— Sean Conlon_

4 Hours Ago

## AI is 'going to change the world,' Wharton's Jeremy Siegel says

Wharton professor emeritus Jeremy Siegel is bullish on artificial intelligence, even as [fears mount over spending](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/06/ai-sell-off-stocks-amazon-oracle.html) for the technology.

"This is probably one of the greatest technological revolutions that we've ever experienced. It's going to change the world in many ways that we don't know," Siegel said on CNBC's "[Closing Bell](https://www.cnbc.com/closing-bell/)" Friday. "It's going to be for the better, because we can produce more and do more with less effort."

"The demand is is astronomical," he added.

Siegel also said that the Dow hitting 50,000 is a sign that there's "a lot of fundamental strength in this economy," forecasting that the recent broadening out is "just the beginning."

_— Sean Conlon_

4 Hours Ago

## Software companies that can use AI 'as an enabler' will win out, BNY says

Shares of software companies have come under considerable pressure this week amid heightened concerns that artificial intelligence could [pose a threat to traditional software models](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/06/ai-anthropic-tools-saas-software-stocks-selloff.html), but some in the industry could still prevail, according to Bob Savage, head of markets macro strategy at BNY.

"Software companies that adapt toward client-specific solutions and integrate AI as an enabler rather than a replacement should regain investor confidence, particularly outside the U.S., where valuations remain more compelling," he said.

In terms of equity markets overall, Savage believes they're positioned well for the remainder of 2026, saying that they look capable of navigating a "more complex investment regime defined by diversification, valuation discipline, and geopolitical realities."

While Savage noted that AI will continue to be a "structural growth driver" for the year, investors are shifting their attention "from broad-based enthusiasm toward differentiated business models, capital efficiency, and defensible revenue streams," he continued.

_— Sean Conlon_

4 Hours Ago

## Bull market is 'aging' rather than 'dead,' investing chief says

Post-earnings market volatility may not signal that bull market is ending — but it can indicate that forecasts are overstretched, according Clark Bellin, investing chief at Bellwether Wealth.

"The bull market is not dead, but it is aging," Bellin said. "We are not be surprised to see investors paying more attention to corporate earnings and profitability."

"Early in bull markets, expectations are low," he added. "But as this bull market progresses into its fourth year, expectations for earnings are rising."

Bellin said he isn't surprised to see rocky trading this month following January's gains. He said investors should "remain opportunistic" when stocks dip, but don't need to feel like they have to buy every pullback.

"2026 should still be a positive year, with plenty of opportunities to buy stocks on sale," he said.

_— Alex Harring_

## Oppenheimer upgrades Roku to buy, says there are 'too many catalysts'

The Roku logo is displayed on a smartphone.

Omar Marques | Lightrocket | Getty Images

Roku has many upcoming catalysts including an Amazon partnership and the Winter Olympics that make it a buying opportunity, according to Oppenheimer.

Analyst Jason Helfstein upgraded the stock to outperform from perform, and established a $105 price target implying more than 22% upside.

"We currently estimate 2026/2027 Platform revenue +15%/16% y/y expolitical/606/Frndly, 2% above Street, however we see a potential bull case for +17%/ +16%."

_— Sarah Min_

5 Hours Ago

## Deutsche Bank upgrades Ares after sell-off

Deutsche Bank has moved off the sidelines on [Ares](https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/ARES/), upgrading the alternative assets manager to buy from hold on Friday.

The stock, along with others with significant private-credit market holdings, has [taken a hit lately](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/03/private-credit-stocks-plummet-on-concern-about-exposure-to-software-industry-disrupted-by-ai.html) due to fears about exposure to industries being disrupted by artificial intelligence. On Thursday, Ares tumbled 11% following its miss on his fourth-quarter after-tax realized income.

However, Deutsche Bank believes the concerns about private credit fundamentals and potential disruption from AI are "overblown" relative to the likelihood of strong fee-related earnings growth remaining intact across its forecast horizon.

"Solid trends around fundraising and deployment point to a strong and durable FRE growth trajectory that should remain near 20% in 2026 and also on a 3-year CAGR \[compound annual growth rate\] basis," analyst Brian Bedell wrote in a note to clients. "Relative to this outlook, we think the sell-off post earnings (and underperformance recently) have created a compelling entry point."

Bedell lowered his price target to $155 from $182, which still implies 27% upside from Thursday's close. The stock is down almost 20% year to date.

_— Michelle Fox_

5 Hours Ago

## Dow surpasses 50,000

Traders react as the Dow Jones Industrial Average surpasses the 50,000 mark on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., Feb. 6, 2026.

Brendan McDermid | Reuters

The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose more than 1,000 points, or more than 2%, on Friday to cross the 50,000 threshold for the first time on record.

In afternoon trading, the 30-stock index gained 1,106 points, or about 2.3%, to reach a fresh high of 50,015.07. That puts its week-to-date jump at more than 2% and its year-to-date climb at around 4%.

_— Sean Conlon_

5 Hours Ago

## Monolithic Power Systems jumps on data center demand

Shares of [Monolithic Power Systems](https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/MPWR/) rose 5% after the chip company reported fourth-quarter results that impressed Wall Street.

Monolithic makes chips that help regulate power for industrial customers including artificial intelligence data centers. It is the main supplier for all the major companies accelerating AI, according to Oppenheimer.

Its revenue jumped about 21% year over year to $751 million led by data center and cloud demand. The company increased its dividend to $2 per share from $1.56 previously. It expects revenues of $770 million to $790 million in the first quarter of 2026.

"MPWR sets up well to outperform the broader semiconductor market with both an improving margin profile and an accelerating top-line outlook, in our view," Oppenheimer analyst Rick Schafer told clients in a Thursday note.

Oppenheimer rates Monolithic as outperform with a price target of $1,300 per share, suggesting about a 12% upside from Thursday's close.

_— Spencer Kimball_

# Stock Market Research: February 6, 2026

## Executive Summary

Friday, February 6, 2026 saw a powerful market rebound after a brutal three-day tech selloff. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged over 1,200 points to close above 50,000 for the first time in history. The S&P 500 posted its best day since May, rising 2%, while the Nasdaq gained 2.18%. The rally was driven by dip-buying in semiconductors, a rotation into "old economy" sectors, and resilient investor confidence that the bull market remains intact despite growing skepticism around AI software valuations.

---

## 1. Major Index Performance

| Index | Close | Change | % Change | Notable |
|-------|-------|--------|----------|---------|
| **Dow Jones Industrial Average** | 50,115.67 | +1,206.95 | **+2.47%** | First close above 50,000 ever |
| **S&P 500** | 6,932.30 | +134.04 | **+1.97%** | Best day since May 2025 |
| **Nasdaq Composite** | 23,031.21 | +490.74 | **+2.18%** | Best day since November 2025 |

### Weekly Performance
- **Dow**: +2.5% for the week, snapping a three-week losing streak
- **S&P 500**: Down for the third time in four weeks despite Friday's rally
- **Nasdaq**: Down ~1.8% for the week, extending its losing streak to four consecutive weeks

### Year-to-Date Performance
- **Dow**: +4%
- **S&P 500**: +1%
- **Nasdaq**: -2%

*Sources: [CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/05/stock-market-today-live-updates.html), [Investopedia](https://www.investopedia.com/stock-market-today-dow-jones-s-and-p-500-02062026-11901010)*

---

## 2. Key Factors Driving the Rebound

### 2.1 Dip-Buying After an Oversold Condition

The Nasdaq had experienced its worst three-day slide since April, shedding more than $1.5 trillion in market value during the week before Friday's session. This extreme selling pressure created an oversold condition that attracted bargain hunters.

> "When you pull the beach ball underwater that quickly in places like Big Tech, certainly software and semis, the bounce back can be breathtaking." — **Chris Galipeau, Senior Market Strategist, Franklin Templeton** ([CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/06/markets/tech-stocks-meltdown-why))

### 2.2 Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang's Comments on AI Demand

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang told CNBC that demand for AI chips has been "going through the roof" and that the AI industry could be reaching an "inflection point." He described the current buildout as potentially the "largest infrastructure buildout in human history." His comments helped reassure semiconductor investors and sent the PHLX Semiconductor Sector Index (SOX) up nearly 6%.

> "This is probably one of the greatest technological revolutions that we've ever experienced." — **Jeremy Siegel, Wharton Professor Emeritus** ([CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/05/stock-market-today-live-updates.html))

### 2.3 Broader Market Rotation into Value and Cyclicals

Capital has been rotating out of high-multiple tech and growth stocks into "old economy" sectors — energy, industrials, materials, consumer staples, and banks. This rotation has provided a floor for the broader market even as tech sold off.

### 2.4 Resilient Earnings Season

The S&P 500 has reported aggregate year-over-year earnings growth of 10.1% for Q4 2025, with estimates pointing toward 13% EPS growth. This strong earnings backdrop provided fundamental support for the bounce.

### 2.5 Bitcoin and Crypto Recovery

Bitcoin, which had plunged to near $60,000 overnight (its lowest since October 2024), rebounded sharply to above $70,700 by market close. This recovery in risk assets helped improve overall market sentiment.

*Sources: [CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/06/markets/tech-stocks-meltdown-why), [CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/05/stock-market-today-live-updates.html), [Investopedia](https://www.investopedia.com/stock-market-today-dow-jones-s-and-p-500-02062026-11901010)*

---

## 3. Sector Analysis

### Friday's S&P 500 Sector Performance

| Sector | Performance | Notes |
|--------|-------------|-------|
| **Information Technology** | **+4.0%** | Led gains; semiconductor rebound |
| **Industrials** | Positive | Caterpillar surged ~7% |
| **Financials** | Positive | Banks at 52-week highs (PNC) |
| **Energy** | Positive | Exxon hit all-time highs |
| **Consumer Staples** | Positive | Coca-Cola at all-time highs |
| **Healthcare** | Positive | Merck at multi-month highs |
| **Materials** | Positive | Steel Dynamics at all-time highs |
| **Communication Services** | **-1.8%** | News Corp -6% |
| **Consumer Discretionary** | **-1.4%** | Dragged by Amazon -5.5% |

Nine of eleven S&P 500 sectors closed in the green. Communication Services and Consumer Discretionary were the only decliners.

### Year-to-Date Sector Trends (The "Great Rotation")

| Winning "Old Economy" Sectors | YTD Performance |
|-------------------------------|-----------------|
| Energy | +15% |
| Consumer Staples | +11% |
| Industrials | +7% |
| Banks | +7% |

| Losing Tech Sectors | YTD Performance |
|---------------------|-----------------|
| S&P 500 Information Technology | -6% |
| iShares Expanded Tech-Software ETF (IGV) | -17% (in last week alone) |

> "The bull market is intact; however, it's not being led by the popular Tech and Growth favorites of investors. Instead, new momentum and leadership are emerging in cyclical and value sectors—Energy, Industrials, Materials, Staples, and Banks." — **Piper Sandler** ([Business Insider](https://www.businessinsider.com/top-stock-sectors-buy-tech-software-sell-energy-industrials-ai-2026-2))

*Sources: [CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/05/stock-market-today-live-updates.html), [Business Insider](https://www.businessinsider.com/top-stock-sectors-buy-tech-software-sell-energy-industrials-ai-2026-2)*

---

## 4. Notable Individual Stock Performances

### Top Gainers

| Stock | Change | Reason |
|-------|--------|--------|
| **Strategy (MSTR)** | +25% | Bitcoin rebound; had plunged 17% Thursday |
| **Roblox (RBLX)** | +10% | Strong earnings report |
| **Gen Digital (GEN)** | +11% | Earnings beat |
| **Nvidia (NVDA)** | +7.8% | Huang's bullish AI demand comments; best day since April |
| **AMD (AMD)** | +8% | Rebound from Wednesday's 17% drop |
| **Caterpillar (CAT)** | +7% | "Old economy" rotation play |
| **Broadcom (AVGO)** | Strong gain | Semiconductor recovery |
| **MARA Holdings (MARA)** | +22% | Crypto rebound |
| **Robinhood (HOOD)** | +14% | Crypto rebound |
| **Coinbase (COIN)** | +13% | Crypto rebound |
| **Monolithic Power (MPWR)** | +5% | Strong Q4 results on data center demand |

### Top Decliners

| Stock | Change | Reason |
|-------|--------|--------|
| **Stellantis (STLA)** | -25% | Business "reset" with ~$26 billion in charges; EV strategy reversal |
| **Molina Healthcare (MOH)** | -26% | Earnings miss; hit lowest since March 2020 |
| **Doximity (DOCS)** | -17% | Disappointing earnings |
| **Coty (COTY)** | -16% | Weak earnings report |
| **Amazon (AMZN)** | -5.5% | $200B capex forecast spooked investors; worst Dow performer |
| **News Corp (NWSA)** | -6% | Worst in Communication Services sector |
| **Salesforce (CRM)** | New 52-week low | AI disruption fears; down 28% YTD |
| **ServiceNow (NOW)** | New 52-week low | AI disruption fears |

### Stocks Hitting All-Time Highs (66 S&P 500 members)

Notable names reaching all-time highs on Friday:
- **Coca-Cola (KO)** — all-time high (IPO 1919)
- **Exxon (XOM)** — all-time high (NYSE listing 1920)
- **Johnson & Johnson (JNJ)** — all-time high (IPO 1944)
- **Hilton Worldwide (HLT)** — all-time high (IPO 2013)
- **Delta Air Lines (DAL)** — all-time high (IPO 2007)
- **Northrop Grumman (NOC)** — all-time high
- **Steel Dynamics (STLD)** — all-time high
- **PNC Financial Services (PNC)** — all-time high

*Sources: [Investopedia](https://www.investopedia.com/stock-market-today-dow-jones-s-and-p-500-02062026-11901010), [CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/05/stock-market-today-live-updates.html), [Bloomberg](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-05/asian-stocks-to-fall-as-us-tech-crypto-extend-dip-markets-wrap)*

---

## 5. Economic News, Earnings & Policy Announcements

### 5.1 Earnings Season Highlights

**Amazon (AMZN)** — Reported Q4 earnings Thursday after the bell. Revenue met expectations, but the company forecast 2026 capital expenditures of **$200 billion** — a 50% year-over-year increase and ~$50 billion more than Wall Street expected. Operating income guidance fell short. Shares dropped ~5.5% Friday.

**Big Tech AI Spending Recap** (past two weeks):
- **Alphabet & Meta**: 2026 infrastructure spending ~2x 2025 levels
- **Amazon**: $200B capex forecast for 2026
- **Microsoft**: Capital spending expected consistent with last quarter (60%+ YoY increase)

**Other Earnings Movers:**
- **Roblox (RBLX)**: Beat expectations, shares +10%
- **Molina Healthcare (MOH)**: Missed estimates badly, shares -26%
- **Stellantis (STLA)**: Announced €22+ billion in charges from EV strategy reversal, preliminary net loss of €19-21 billion, no dividend — shares -25%
- **Monolithic Power (MPWR)**: Revenue +21% YoY to $751M on data center demand, shares +5%

### 5.2 The Anthropic/AI Software Disruption Catalyst

The week's broader selloff was triggered by **Anthropic's release of new Claude Cowork plugins** (late January/early February) demonstrating autonomous capabilities in legal review, accounting, and coding tasks. This sparked fears that AI agents could cannibalize SaaS subscription models, leading to a **~$1 trillion wipeout** in software and services stocks over the week.

> "Consensus about software companies has flipped to them being AI victims, not beneficiaries." — **Steve Sosnick, Chief Strategist, Interactive Brokers** ([CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/06/markets/tech-stocks-meltdown-why))

**Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang** pushed back, calling the idea that AI will replace software "illogical."

### 5.3 Federal Reserve Commentary

Two Fed officials gave contrasting assessments on Friday:
- **Fed Governor Philip Jefferson** (Brookings Institution): Expressed "cautious optimism," noting the unemployment rate at 4.4% has "changed little," suggesting job market stabilization.
- **SF Fed President Mary Daly**: Highlighted that working households don't feel optimistic, with consumer surveys showing expectations of rising unemployment and scarcer jobs.

### 5.4 Consumer Sentiment

A U.S. survey showed consumer sentiment improved marginally in early February, though lingering worries about the labor market and rising cost of living persist.

### 5.5 Other Market Data

| Asset | Level | Change |
|-------|-------|--------|
| 10-Year Treasury Yield | 4.21% | +3 bps |
| WTI Crude Oil | $63.40/barrel | Slightly higher |
| Gold Futures | $4,975/oz | +2% |
| Silver Futures | ~$77/oz | Recovering |
| Bitcoin | ~$70,700 | +10% from overnight lows |
| U.S. Dollar Index | 97.63 | Slightly lower |

### 5.6 IPO Activity

**Once Upon a Farm (OFRM)** — Jennifer Garner's children's food company debuted on the NYSE, pricing its IPO at $18/share, raising ~$200 million with an implied market cap of ~$724 million.

*Sources: [Investopedia](https://www.investopedia.com/stock-market-today-dow-jones-s-and-p-500-02062026-11901010), [Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/business/media-telecom/global-software-stocks-hit-by-anthropic-wake-up-call-ai-disruption-2026-02-04/), [CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/05/stock-market-today-live-updates.html)*

---

## 6. Market Sentiment & Investor Reactions

### Prevailing Themes

1. **"Buy the Dip" Mentality Held**: Despite the worst three-day Nasdaq selloff since April, investors stepped in aggressively on Friday. The fact that 66 S&P 500 stocks hit 52-week highs shows broad participation beneath the tech weakness.

2. **The "Great Rotation" is Accelerating**: Capital is moving decisively from growth/tech into value/cyclical sectors. This is being interpreted not as a market breakdown but as a healthy broadening.

3. **AI Skepticism ≠ Market Bearishness**: Investors are becoming more selective about AI winners vs. losers, rather than abandoning the market entirely. Chipmakers (who supply the infrastructure) are gaining while software companies (potentially disrupted by AI) are losing.

4. **Crypto Volatility**: Bitcoin's 50% drawdown from its peak followed by a sharp recovery to $70K+ shows extreme sentiment swings in risk assets.

### Sentiment Indicators
- **VIX/Fear**: Risk-off sentiment dominated earlier in the week, but Friday's broad rally indicates the fear was short-lived
- **Breadth**: 66 stocks at new 52-week highs vs. only 11 at new 52-week lows in the S&P 500 — strongly positive breadth

*Sources: [CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/06/markets/tech-stocks-meltdown-why), [CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/05/stock-market-today-live-updates.html)*

---

## 7. Analyst Commentary & Expert Opinions

### Bull Case

> **Jeremy Siegel, Wharton Professor Emeritus**: "This is probably one of the greatest technological revolutions that we've ever experienced. It's going to change the world." He said the Dow hitting 50,000 is a sign of "a lot of fundamental strength in this economy" and that the market broadening is "just the beginning." ([CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/05/stock-market-today-live-updates.html))

> **Clark Bellin, Bellwether Wealth**: "The bull market is not dead, but it is aging. 2026 should still be a positive year, with plenty of opportunities to buy stocks on sale." ([CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/05/stock-market-today-live-updates.html))

> **Tom Essaye, Sevens Report Research**: "The negativity surrounding AI-related tech is getting pretty intense. If AI is more resilient than expected (which has been the case in each test so far over the past three years), then there are opportunities [for buying] developing." ([CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/06/markets/tech-stocks-meltdown-why))

> **Seana Smith, Global X ETFs**: "The bar for Big Tech remains extremely high. Markets are only rewarding AI investment when it is paired with clear, durable revenue growth." ([CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/06/markets/tech-stocks-meltdown-why))

### Cautious/Rotation Camp

> **Piper Sandler Analysts**: "New momentum and leadership are emerging in cyclical and value sectors — Energy, Industrials, Materials, Staples, and Banks." ([Business Insider](https://www.businessinsider.com/top-stock-sectors-buy-tech-software-sell-energy-industrials-ai-2026-2))

> **Goldman Sachs Analysts**: "The investor search for insulation from AI disruption risk has accelerated the ongoing cyclical rally." They examined which industries are least exposed to AI automation. ([Business Insider](https://www.businessinsider.com/top-stock-sectors-buy-tech-software-sell-energy-industrials-ai-2026-2))

> **Bob Savage, BNY**: "Software companies that adapt toward client-specific solutions and integrate AI as an enabler rather than a replacement should regain investor confidence." ([CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/05/stock-market-today-live-updates.html))

### Bear/Risk Warnings

> **Jim Reid, Deutsche Bank**: "Recent months have seen a shift from the 'every tech stock is a winner' mindset to a more brutal landscape of winners and losers." ([CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/06/markets/tech-stocks-meltdown-why))

> **Steve Sosnick, Interactive Brokers**: "Crowded trades are difficult to exit. Assets that have been granted premium valuations, whether through rational expectations or speculative fervor, are more prone to messy selloffs if perceptions and/or momentum change." ([CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/06/markets/tech-stocks-meltdown-why))

> **Nick Dempsey, Barclays**: Called it "just does not seem realistic" that AI can fully supplant industry-specific software tools, but acknowledged that in markets this touchy, "headlines about the possibility are clearly not helpful." ([CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/06/markets/tech-stocks-meltdown-why))

### Top Brokerage S&P 500 Targets for 2026

Per Reuters, top brokerages expect the S&P 500 to extend its rally in 2026, with investors piling into AI plays and betting on reduced borrowing costs to sustain momentum.

---

## 8. Key Takeaways

1. **The Dow hit 50,000 for the first time** — a historic milestone driven by broad-based buying in industrials, financials, energy, and consumer staples rather than the traditional tech leadership.

2. **A massive sector rotation is underway** — the S&P 500 IT sector is the worst performer in 2026 (-6% YTD), while Energy (+15%), Consumer Staples (+11%), Industrials (+7%), and Banks (+7%) are leading.

3. **AI is splitting into winners and losers** — chipmakers (Nvidia, AMD, Broadcom) are benefiting from insatiable infrastructure demand, while software companies (Salesforce, ServiceNow, Adobe) face existential disruption fears from Anthropic's agentic AI tools.

4. **Big Tech's $200B+ capex plans are a double-edged sword** — they signal massive chip demand (bullish for semis) but concern investors about returns on investment (bearish for the hyperscalers themselves).

5. **The bull market appears intact but changing character** — leadership is broadening from a narrow set of tech megacaps to a wider array of cyclical and value sectors, consistent with late-cycle market behavior.

6. **Friday's rebound was sharp but doesn't erase the weekly damage** — the Nasdaq still ended the week lower for the fourth straight week, and the software selloff wiped out nearly $1 trillion in market value over the past week.

---

*Research compiled: February 7, 2026*
*Sources: CNBC, CNN Business, Investopedia, Reuters, Bloomberg, Business Insider, Yahoo Finance*
